itemDescription: English rugby union and rugby league footballer

wikipedia_page.main: Alfred "Alf" Ernest Wood (27 November 1883 – 15 February 1963) was an English dual-code international rugby union and professional rugby league footballer who played in the 1900s, 1910s and 1920s. He played representative level rugby union (RU) for England, and at club level for Gloucester RFC, as a fullback, i.e. number 15, and representative level rugby league (RL) for Great Britain, and at club level for Oldham (Heritage No. 119), as a fullback, i.e. number 1.

response: Following his appearances for Australia on the inaugural Kangaroo tour of England in 1908 several English clubs made offers for him to stay and he reached agreement with the Oldham. For the next four seasons he featured in a star-studded team including Arthur Anlezark, Kangaroo Tom McCabe and English representatives James "Jim" Lomas, Alf Wood and Albert Avery. Oldham were Championship finalists for each of those four years. Deane played right-, i.e. number 3, in Oldham's 3-7 defeat by Wigan in the Championship Final during the 1908–09 season at The Willows, Salford on Saturday 1 May 1909, played, and was captain in Oldham's 13-7 victory over Wigan in the Championship Final during the 1909–10 season, and played, and was captain in Oldham's 20-7 victory over Wigan in the Championship Final during the 1910–11 season.

link_mentions.page: List of England national rugby union players
List of Great Britain national rugby league team players

response: In 1913, both Billy Hall, and Dave Holland left Gloucester RFC to join Oldham, following Alf Wood who had made the same journey in 1908. Alf Wood and Dave Holland both played at Oldham until 1921, and Billy Hall played there until 1925. All three men played in Great Britain's "Rorke's Drift" Test match against Australia in 1914, with Alf Wood kicking the four goals that would be the difference in the end.
Alfred or Alf Wood may refer to:
*Alf Wood (footballer, born 1915) (1915–2001), English goalkeeper and football manager
*Alf Wood (rugby) (1883–1963), rugby union and rugby league footballer of the 1900s and 1910s for England (RU), Gloucester, Great Britain (RL), England, and Oldham

In 1913, both Billy Hall, and Dave Holland left Gloucester RFC to join Oldham, following Alf Wood who had made the same journey in 1908. Alf Wood and Dave Holland both played at Oldham until 1921, and Billy Hall played there until 1925. All three men played in Great Britain's "Rorke's Drift" Test match against Australia in 1914, with Alf Wood kicking the four goals that would be the difference in the end.

link_mentions.page: Template talk:Great Britain squad – 1920 Australia & New Zealand Tourists
response: The photograph entitled Great Britain Rugby League Touring Team - Australasia 1924 does not show Ernest Jones (rugby league), and Bobby Lloyd but they did play in Test matches on this tour. Alf Wood (rugby) (), William Reid (rugby league) (position?), George Rees (rugby) (), are shown on the photograph, they didn't play in Test matches on this tour, but they may have played in tour matches, or had to withdraw from the tour after the photograph was taken. Joseph Doyle (rugby league) (), shown on the photograph, didn't play in Test matches on this tour, but he did play in tour matches on this tour.
